class_notes:
The Colloquium will consider the origins, development, and meaning of the professions in America from the Revolution to the present. In doing this, the course will thus in effect explore the special place of expertise, and the unelected authority claimed by expertise, in a democracy. Each week students will read assignment drawn from both primary and secondary materials (including some fiction) and then meet to discuss the material. Emphasis will be placed on the evolution of professional lawyers, doctors, ministers, artists, and sports figures, as well as on the fraught story of professional opportunities for women and minorities. 
 
No exams. There will be one research paper, 15-20 pages, on a topic related to the course but of the studentÂ¿s choosing.  
 
Grading: Class participation 35% (roughly); research paper (65%) roughly.  
 
Required books:  
 
1.) Benjamin Franklin, Autobiography 
2.) S. Lewis, Arrowsmith 
 
3.) R. Kahn, Boys of Summer 
 
4.) S. Turow, One L 
 
5.) Paul Starr, The Social Transformation of American Medicine
